lg.l: Even the boundless sea would lose its watery nature, if after reducing it
the clouds stopped giving it back again.

div.p: (i-ḷ). aḷavillātakaṭalun taṉṉiyalpu kuṟaiyum,mēkantāṉ ataṉaikkuṟait tataṉkaṭ peyyātu viṭumāyiṉ, (e-ṟu).
The meaning ... : The immeasurable ocean would be diminished in its own nature if clouds themselves stopped pouring [back] into it after drawing from it.

ummai - ciṟappummai. taṉṉiyalpu kuṟaitalāvatu nīrvāḻuyirkaḷ piṟavāmaiyum maṇimutalāyiṉa paṭāmaiyumām. īṇṭuk kuṟaittaleṉṟatu mukattalai; atu “kaṭalkuṟai paṭuttanīr kalkuṟai paṭaveṟintu” eṉpataṉāṉu maṟika. maḻaikku mutalāya kaṭaṟkum maḻaivēṇṭu meṉpatām.

The particle -um ["Even"] shows high degree/abundance. [By] the diminution of [the ocean]'s nature, [what is meant is that] beings that live in the water would no longer be born and [precious gems] such as pearls would no longer be produced. Here, [by] diminution, [the poet refers to?] the drawing-off [of water]; one should recognize this [usage] also in [the following quotation from the Paripāṭal]: "Casting the water produced by diminishing the sea so that it falls upon the stone mountain (?) ... " [The idea] is that even the ocean, which precedes rain, [also] needs rain.
ivai yēḻu pāṭṭāṉum maḻai ulaka naṭakkaṟ kētuvātal kūṟappaṭṭatu.
Through these seven poems, it has been proclaimed that rain is the cause of the continued existence (more lit. "going/course") of the world.
(i - ḷ.) nilamēyaṉṟi neṭiyakaṭalum taṉatu taṉmai kuṟaiyum; miṉṉi maḻaiyāṉatu peyyāviṭiṉ, (e - ṟu).
The meaning ... : Apart from the Earth, the wide sea, too, would have its own nature curtailed if clouds stopped thundering and pouring.
taṭinteṉpataṟku, kūṟupaṭuttu eṉṟu poruḷuraippāru muḷar. itu nīruḷ vāḻvaṉavum paṭuvaṉavuṅ keṭumeṉṟatu. ivai nāṉkiṉāṉum poruṭ kēṭu kūṟiṉār; poruḷ keṭa iṉpaṅkeṭu meṉpataṉāl iṉpakkēṭu kūṟiṟṟilar.

As for [the form] "taṭintu," there are also those who explain its meaning as "dividing" [i.e. "reducing"—rather than "striking," i.e. with lightning]. This [verse] says that beings that those things that live and are produced in water would be lost. With these four [preceding verses, the poet] has described the loss of material welfare; because happiness also is lost when welfare is lost, he has not described the loss of happiness.
